captions.text: INTERVIEWER: Damn.
Lucky.

Wait, tell me about
this place.

DYLAN RIEDER: I don't want to
reveal too much information.

INTERVIEWER: You've gotta
tell me something, Bro.

DYLAN RIEDER: It's just
a private facility me
and some guys got.

I designed the [INAUDIBLE]
corner,
that was my main piece.

INTERVIEWER: And we're
not supposed to
be filming in here?

DYLAN RIEDER: I don't think
we're supposed to
be filming in here.
Whatever, I pay rent, so.

I might get yelled
at for this.
But, whatever, my life.
PATRICK O'DELL: What's up?

Welcome back to Epicly
Later'd.

This episode's about Dylan
Rieder whose hands down one of
the best pros out right now.

He just came out with a part
on gravis, just him as the
whole video, and it's amazing.

I guess the only reason he made
it is because he wasn't

really that satisfied with the
Alien Workshop part that came
out a year ago.

Dylan's amazing, I hope
you enjoy the episode.

DYLAN RIEDER: I grew up in
Westminster, a little north of

Huntington Beach, kind of like
Korean, Mexican town, a lot of
pool halls, a lot of pho.

I don't think anybody's really
from Westminster, none of whom
that skates.

Just Huntington Beach, Dells
from Huntington Beach.

I think, Templeton's
from Huntington.

Like you ever been to that murdy
park down there, it's

like a little ashtray park, I
think Templeton designed it.

INTERVIEWER: Yeah,
the famous one.

DYLAN RIEDER: No, I think in
Huntington Park's the famous
one over by the high school.

Then there's another one before
that, that was smaller,
before Huntington Park.

But we used to go there,
because we were too

intimidated to go to Huntington
Park, because

that's where Andrew went and all
those those Warren Avenue
crew dudes, at the time.
I was like 11, maybe 10.

I remember seeing like Andrew
at Huntington Park for the

first time, I was pretty
star struck.

Saw Penny there a couple times
when I was little.

That old Penny footage
there is awesome.
He rips that place.

It's not there anymore, they
took it out, demolished it to

extend the football fucking
field, which is stupid.

INTERVIEWER: So how
old are you now?
DYLAN RIEDER: 21.

INTERVIEWER: OK, that seems like
you'd be real young when
that was going on.

DYLAN RIEDER: Yeah,
I was super young.
Such a little shit head.

MARK OBLOW: I first met Dylan,
I was doing a photo shoot for

Quicksilver for their
youth campaign.

I would shoot whoever
they would bring.

They would bring models,
or whatever.

And then at that point Dylan
actually had come in, like

they picked him as a
little boy model.

And he had come in like that
like, and they're like, oh, we

brought a little skater guy,
and I was super anti.

I was like, [PHEW], totally
get away from me.

We shot some photos, and then
they needed action photos.

So then I sent Tim to go shoot
some stuff with Ortiz, because

I was like, I ain't even going
to waste my fucking time.

I talked to Ortiz later, and I
was like, hey, how'd that go?

And Ortiz was like, Dude,
he's pretty gnarly.

And I'm like, what
do you mean?
What was he pretty gnarly?

He's actually like, Smith Grind
this rail and he kick
flipped down these stairs.
And I was just like, what?

Get the fuck out of
here, whatever.

So then, Damn Am comes around,
he basically is like, can I
come enter the Damn Am?
Can I enter under Quicksilver?

And I'm like, yeah go for it,
whatever, it's totally cool.

And then next thing you know,
he won the contest.

And I was just like,
what the fuck?

From that point on, he basically
went on pretty much

every single trip that I
did for Quicksilver.
These are the fucked up ones.

Like this, this was the
first Miami trip.

That was his first
trip with us.

That was with Janoski, and
Donny Barley, and Reece.
But like that was--
INTERVIEWER: He's got braces?

MARK OBLOW: Yeah,
he's got braces.

He was such a little,
like, little guy.
The old team right there.

GREG HUNT: I mean, that's
something I even, like, I

skate with him all the
time and I forget.

Like when he was like 12, he
was going on trips with the

Quicksilver guys, like Reece,
Stefan, and he was just like

the little kid with
men, you know.

And then also with Osiris, I
think he went on like a bunch

of trips with Jerry,
and all those guys.

So he's got like some
pretty deep roots.

Like, once in a while I'll see
these old photos, be like, Oh

yeah, were like, one of
those little kids.

Misled Youth, or whatever,
was his favorite video.

And like, he had like super skin
tight pants, he was like

13 years old, he's like one of
those kids, like lip sliding

15-stair hand rails,
or something.

Going out with his buddies at
night, like lighting stuff up

like a bunch of like
15-year-old kids.

Like trying to skate like most
gigantic hand rail and almost
killing themselves, you know.

MARK OBLOW: Jerry has a portrait
of him somewhere.

And it's just like this portrait
of this baby, it's

like Dylan, it's like
this baby face.

JERRY HSU: I first met Dylan
when I rode for Osiris.

And I think Chris Pastras was
our team manager at the time,

and I don't know where
he found him.

I think he went to like a
contest or something, and just

found this kid, and just brought
him on some trips.

That's how I'd first met him,
I'd never heard of him, or

seen photos of him, or
anything like that.

But I just trust Chris, because
he had good taste.

Me and Louie on tour we would
kind of try to take care of

him and make sure he
didn't get into too
much trouble or anything.
He was so young.
He was really quiet.
He never said anything.

He was just this really quiet
kid, with like braces.

It's funny, like he
was really shy.

Girls always wanted to
talk to him, and
like hug him and stuff.

He was just like this adorable
little kid, and like he was

just so shy, and like he didn't
really-- and it was all

really new to him, just being
sponsored and traveling.

You could tell he was
a mature kid.
He wasn't like just some spaz.

Like normally kids at that age
you can tell that they don't
really know how to skate yet.

I mean, maybe they could do hard
tricks, but they can't
really skate.

But Dylan could skate
everything, and like skate
really well.

Like, we liked him
a lot right away.
We really liked his skating.

DYLAN RIEDER: When Osiris came
out with the Subject to Change

video, I shared a part
with "the Butcher".

I was excited, it was the first
video I was filming for.
I was like 15, 14.

When I was that age all I really
did was like skate
rails and stuff.

GREG HUNT: He kind of got
labeled as like a little rail

kid, because that's all he was
really skating was rails.

Once again, seeing a little
kid in the beginning.

He thinks one way,
and then he gets
influenced by someone else.

He really got influenced with
Tony T and those guys.

And Tony was, I think, a big
influence with him, and so was
Donnie Barley.

And those guys, what kind of
set them apart, was their
being able to skate tranny.

It really hit him, and I think
the way he looked at skating
bowls, and skating tranny.

And, like I actually made him
enter the first contest.
And he did pretty bad.

And then he went back the second
year, and he actually

got 13th place, which is pretty
gnarly for Marseilles.

This was actually that one
he rode in Marseilles.

That was the one where
he got 13th place.

That was pretty gnarly,
stoked on out.

INTERVIEWER: That was
an Am contest?
MARK OBLOW: No, it was pro.

It was pro, that was when he
did, and that was before

anyone, I mean, I saw doing
them was the no-comply
tail-side reverts.

He did that in there,
in one of his runs.

And then he did like, there was
a wall, a vert wall, and

he did like, kick flip front
side wall rides, and kick flip

backside wall rides, but like
super high and popping.

He was skating more
like, doing more
technical and flip stuff.

It was good, I think, it was
just good for him to like

break out of the little
rail kid deal.

JERRY HSU: After all the Osiris
stuff, I would just
kind of see him around.

I didn't see him for years,
and then he just grew up.

I guess I feel kind
of like proud.

It's not like I played like
a big part in his life, or

anything, but it was just cool
to see him go from like a

little kid to just like a full
blown, like totally well
respected skater.

INTERVIEWER: Are you psyched
to be in another episode?

DYLAN RIEDER: Yeah, I feel like
it's good that I make my

cameo every three or
four episodes.
That's good.

INTERVIEWER: You're in the
[INAUDIBLE] for no reason.
DYLAN RIEDER: Yeah like--

INTERVIEWER: [INAUDIBLE]
occasionally pan over to you
[INAUDIBLE]

DYLAN RIEDER: Yeah, Yeah, I
don't know, that day I just
felt like being in an episode.

title: Dylan Rieder 1 of 4 - Epicly Later'd - VICE

comments.author: DJDEMO1000

comments.text:
hate how everybody is jocking the rolled up pants thing. quit with that 
"fucking awesome" uniform kids. that shit is corny. he's the only one 
really pulling it off. and that's only cause he looks great on skateboard. 
his frontside heelflips are so steezy. it's so corny when i see other pros 
doing it especially. who's that one fag that skated that ridiculous 
competition with him? mike mo? anyway i was watching dylans footage on the 
rob dydrek competition x-games on steroids shit but that mike mo dude i 
think that's his name. he had his hair cut and his pants rolled up. totally 
trying to get bitches. with rolled up pants....the austin and dylan look. ﻿
comments.author: brokenupbeat

comments.text:
+Dylan It's so fucked to see skateboarders who don't express their own 
style and creativity. It's almost as if, there's a factory somewhere with 
one type of skater mold and all skaters nowadays came from it lol. You're 
right, man. Their perspectives are hella twisted. The other day, I saw some 
kid here online hating on "Blind: Video Days" claiming that nobody was 
doing anything "big or video worthy". Kids nowadays, just wanna see someone 
switch 3 flip a 26 stair, or they wanna see someone hardflip backlip a 17 
stair handrail. Don't get me wrong, monsterous sets and handrails are 
gnarly beyond gnarly, but there's more to skating then just huge sets and 
handrails. The Reynolds 3 x Shake Junt collab look dope. You can't go wrong 
with a pair of Reynolds, dude knows how to make a perfect shoe lol. I've 
heard nothin but good things when it comes Figgy's Emericas. They're simple 
and to the point, and I'm sure they skate like a dream. Yooo, if you find 
somewhere online that's sellin more than 1 pair of Braydon's Low Pro 
Emericas, lemme know! Lmao. I wanted the Green/black/green ones for the 
longest time. So sick. I'm bummed he left Emerica. Why did he leave, 
though? I just know he left, but I've never researched why. All I 
practically skate is ES lol. I was so bummed when eS "went of business" for 
a minute. I mean, they're still on the rocks, but thank the Skate Gods that 
they re-released the Accels lol. They're pretty much the same as before, 
just more true size and somewhat durable. The ONLY drawback, is the lack of 
colorways lol, but I can't complain. It's just sick to have um and be able 
to get um. Emerica really is one of the best shoe companies around. They're 
so many companies nowadays, that aren't run by skaters for skaters. How in 
the hell did "New Balance" get into the skate scene lol. That's what I 
wanna know.
comments.author: MC Infliction

comments.text:
+brokenupbeat That's sick, man. I'm hoping the baggy jeans and puffy skate 
shoes come back lol. I just hope the dreads and super super small wheels 
don't come back lol.  Man, Matt tore Love the fuck up. Him and Oyola. It's 
sad he's no longer with us.
comments.author: MC Infliction

comments.text:
+MC Infliction dudes in NY are going back to the baggy jeans. actually a 
lot of the kids are rocking the matt reason look out east rn.
comments.author: brokenupbeat

comments.text:
+MC Infliction And oh yeah i would totally recommend the Herman G6 vulc. I 
don't know about the original but the vulc i know skates amazing. I skated 
a pair for a bout a week. My friend let me borrow.
comments.author: Dylan

comments.text:
+MC Infliction
Lol I know dude..they're just sheep with no personality. They find the pro 
everyone is dick riding and try their best to steal that pro's Identity. I 
feel sorry for these kids growing up with a hella wrong outlook on skating. 
Smh. Stay gold is the shit. One of my go-to videos these days for sure. I 
really want the reynolds 3 x shake junt collab. Also wouldn't mind having a 
pair of Braydons shoes. Which is super rare. I'm skating the "laced" right 
now..hella board feel but i was thinking about trying figgy's new shoe 
because its basically the laced with more padding around the ankle.  
Emerica is all i skate pretty much.
comments.author: Dylan

comments.text:
+Dylan Haha, yo! I feel ya. Man, everywhere you look nowadays, kids 
steadily and readily jock someone's style. Having someone influence style 
is one thing, but flat out copying their wardrobe is another lol. "Stay 
Gold" is so fucking gnarly. Damn near all I watched in 2010. I wanna get a 
pair of the Templeton 3s again, like the purple/black joints. I'm 
considering getting the Herman G6, though. They look dope, and I've only 
gotten a couple pairs of Vulcs. I got the Mike Mo Lakai x Girl edits, and I 
dug um. I just ain't trying to fork up money for a pair of Vulcs that rip 
in a week lol. You skated the G6s? Also, what Vulcanized shoes would you 
recommend?
comments.author: MC Infliction

comments.text:
+MC Infliction and yeah i don't really do the rolled cuff either. My style 
looks like i just jumped right out of the kids n emerica video lol.
comments.author: Dylan

comments.text:
+MC Infliction
I hear you man I'm right there with you in that same time era. Was the best 
times in skateboarding in my opinion. We had classic video parts coming out 
like Yeah right, Flip sorry, really sorry etc. I feel like skateboarding is 
kinda drifting some place I don't like very much. Good thing for us who 
have those memories and history because that's what will keep me focused. 
That and my love for skateboarding of course. Yeah though, Dylan didn't 
invent that that's for sure. I'd say grease lightning did haha.
comments.author: Dylan

comments.text:
+Dylan Good point. I'm stuck in the year(s) 2000-2008 when it comes to 
skate fashion (Before everyone went Vulc and tight jeans, not that there's 
anything wrong with that, I just love semi-puffy shoes like the eS Accels 
and somewhat baggy jeans, and that's where my mind set is lol. I'm not 
talking puffy like D3 puffy or baggy jeans to the point where it's like 
wearin a parachute lol). I know all about the skinny jeans, wore um myself 
a few times lol, but never thought it would be possible to roll um up that 
far. He rocks um, tho. Dude is gnarly. If he wasn't as gnarly as he is, I'd 
say they look goofy, but he rips too hard. Therefore, I can dig the look.
comments.author: MC Infliction

comments.text:
+MC Infliction
Well their is a difference in the look when you one person has big ghetto 
ass jeans and one person is going for the greaser look with skinny jeans.
comments.author: Dylan

comments.text:
+Dylan Ah, fuck. I thought we were discussin the "rolled up cuff" look lol. 
If we're talkin the "rolled up ROLLED UP" look, then definitely, this dude 
started it. Had never seen anyone do it before him.
comments.author: MC Infliction

comments.text:
+MC Infliction
Nah p-rod wore baggy ass pants and just had them rolled maybe once at the 
bottom..Really nothing comparable to Dylan's style.
comments.author: Dylan

comments.text: +MC Infliction i don't ever remember p-rod wearing skinny jeans.
comments.author: brokenupbeat

comments.text:
+brokenupbeat Nah nah, Paul Rodriguez was doing that back in the Yeah Right 
days. I'm sure he wasn't the first to do it, but everyone used to do that. 
Dylan didn't invent that look lol. Not by any means.
comments.author: MC Infliction
